value: how YouTube went from a hobbyist paradise to a whole industry

Hey guys, Jimmy here, welcome to my first YouTube video. I'm going to be very famous and get a lot of money from this, but I don't know how to yet. But hey, check this out, I found this really cool site, where apparently, they offer a course, on how to make a living off YouTube. It's quite expensive but at least you do save the one dollar. So um I definitely want to do this, let's check it out... Let's see what happens
[jimmy] I just spent 999$ on your course with my mom's credit card...
[jimmy] Can you help me make a lot of money on YouTube?

[vivian] Wait! What we CAN do is show you just how Youtube went from an hobby to an industry that makes many people tons of money. We are really good at what we do! We are super trustworthy and we have the best dataset! Check this out...
Manoel Horta Ribeiro and Robert West (2011)

The YouNiverse dataset is a large collection of English-language YouTube metadata from over 136k channels and 72.9M videos published between May 2005 and October 2019. YouNiverse also comprises channel-level time-series data with weekly subscriber and view counts, as well as a table specifying which videos a set of 449M anonymous users commented on.

The SponsorBlock database is the core of the open-source crowdsourced SponsorBlock browser extension. The extension aims to skip sponsor segments in YouTube videos. Users submit when a sponsor happens from the extension, and the extension automatically skips sponsors it knows about.
[jimmy] Okay, fine. You know what you are doing. So how do I make money?
[kaleb] To know that we know what we know, and that we do not know what we do not know, that is true knowledge...
[daniel] He's trying to say that in order to master something, you need to first understand it. We have researched several questions, just for you, about what the data tell us.
Click any question to jump to that section **I KNOW THIS BIT IS A BIT UGLY**

How have channels evolved from indie to professional?
YouTube grew from 338k uploads in 2008 to over 15.2 million in 2018. This rapid rise changed which categories became more or less common, and how creators approached their content.
Jimmy, what category do you want to explore?
evolved over time. Check out the full visualization below!
Want to compare two categories side by side? Pick Category A and Category B below!
What enabled indie channels to become professional-minded?
[jimmy] Okay but how long is this going to take?! My mom is already wondering why her card is being declined.
[kaleb] All human wisdom is contained in these two words — wait and hope.
[kaleb] It's Dumas... Anyway, I hate to break it to you, but you might be waiting a while.

[kaleb] The median time between posting your first video and obtaining your first sponsor is 1108 days or around 3 years! It also takes a median of 148 videos!
Note the logarithmic x axes. The right plot seems to follow a log-normal distribtion, whereas the left plot obtained $\lambda = 0.429\pm 0.017$ with a Box-Cox transformation, suggesting it is gamma-like.
[jimmy] Three years!!! I want to throw up. But what kind of stats do I need to get my first sponsor? Maybe if I buy enough bot accounts...

[kaleb] Every heard of the sunk cost fallacy? A story for another day. Metrics your channel will likely need to reach before your first sponsor depend on the category of videos you want to make. How about you pick one?

[kaleb] On median, you would need a total of around views and subscribers. Yould would also need to have published videos on median. In comparison, the medians of the global distributions over all categories are views, subscribers, and videos
Note the logarithmic x axes, and the logarithmic y axis for activity. All distributions seem to be log-normal, apart from activity, which seems to follow a power law. This might suggest that the activity has little-to-no effect on getting sponsored.

[jimmy] There are definitely some differences between categories, but I still don't know what to pick... And the longer I take to decide, the closer I get to having to explain a 1k transfer to "sheNaNigans incoporated". Aargh! Do I really have to choose or can I just pick whatever and switch once I get sponsored?

[kaleb] Interesting strategy... It does happen but only quite rarely. If we look at the 6 months before the first sponsor and the 6 months after, and we compare the most common video categories in both periods, we get a sense of what kind of transitions people make.
Note the connections shown below are logarithmic.
